summary: A letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to defense counsel in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, notifying them of potential evidence and a witness the government may introduce at trial. The evidence includes emails suggesting Maxwell provided access to women for influential men, including the Duke of York, and the witness is a former employee of Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330). The letter discusses evidence of her conduct in providing access to women for influential men, including Jeffrey Epstein and others.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the person with whom the defendant (Maxwell) engaged in conduct. Also the employer of a potential witness from 2005-2006.

persons.name: Duke of York
persons.role: Royal figure / Alleged recipient of introductions
persons.context: Referenced in a described email where the defendant allegedly made arrangements to introduce him to 'pretty' girls for '2 legged sight seeing.'

persons.name: Doug Band
persons.context: Referenced in a described email where the defendant told him she was arranging a dinner for him and others.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for the defendant, recipient of this letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Attorney for the defendant, recipient of this letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Jeffrey Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney for the defendant, recipient of this letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Bobbi Stemheim
persons.context: Attorney for the defendant, recipient of this letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, whose office sent this letter.

connections.description: The document references the defendant's conduct with Jeffrey Epstein, indicating their association in the alleged crimes.
An email described in the letter shows Maxwell making arrangements to introduce the Duke of York to 'pretty' girls.
An email described in the letter shows Maxwell telling Doug Band she was arranging a dinner for him.
Everdell is listed as defense counsel receiving this notification letter from the prosecution.
Menninger is listed as defense counsel receiving this notification letter from the prosecution.
Pagliuca is listed as defense counsel receiving this notification letter from the prosecution.
Stemheim is listed as defense counsel receiving this notification letter from the prosecution.

events.title: Government Notice of Potential Trial Evidence
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office notifies defense counsel of evidence it may introduce at Ghislaine Maxwell's trial, including emails and witness testimony.

events.title: Employment Period of Potential Witness
events.description: A potential witness (name redacted) was employed by Jeffrey Epstein from approximately 2005 to 2006.

locations: Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
Cohen & Gresser LLP, 800 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10022
Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C., 150 East Tenth Avenue, Denver, CO 80203
Law Offices of Bobbi C. Stemheim, 33 West 19th Street-4th Fl., New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The government intended to introduce evidence showing Ghislaine Maxwell took steps to 'please other influential men by providing them with access to women she selected for them,' beyond her conduct with Jeffrey Epstein.
One specific email described Maxwell making arrangements for the 'Duke of York' to be introduced to 'pretty' girls for what she called '2 legged sight seeing.'
Another email described Maxwell telling Doug Band she was arranging a dinner for him and others.
The government planned to call a witness who was employed by Jeffrey Epstein from approximately 2005-2006 to testify about certain documentary evidence.
The evidence was argued to be admissible both as direct evidence of the crimes and under Rule 404(b) to show intent, plan, knowledge, etc.
